content.webTitle: Boris Johnson ‘should take responsibility for Nazanin gaffes’

fields.headline: Boris Johnson ‘should take responsibility for Nazanin gaffes’
fields.bodyText: The husband of the British-Iranian woman imprisoned in Tehran has said Boris Johnson should take responsibility for his mistakes in her case as the couple ended their hunger strike. Richard Ratcliffe and his wife, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, had been refusing food for 15 days in protest at her imprisonment. More than 100 MPs, including the Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, had visited his makeshift camp outside the Iranian embassy in London to show support. His wife, who has been in prison since 2016 after being accused of spying, also ended her protest on Saturday. “It was getting hard for me but I’m sure it was much harder for her,” he told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme. “I’m relieved because I wouldn’t have wanted her to push it much longer.” His wife had been under “a lot of pressure” from guards to break the strike and had been feeling nauseous. “It had been a real struggle for her the last few days ... I think she will go to the clinic as soon as possible,” he said. “My experience has been sitting on a doorstep, lots of people coming up to me with flowers and cards, so it has been emotionally great, although a physical challenge.” His wife had eaten some porridge with apple and banana, he said. The couple’s five-year-old daughter, Gabriella, understood her parents were ending their protest, but had suggested “Daddy should carry on for a bit” as Zaghari-Ratcliffe had not been released. “But we clarified that I wouldn’t,” he said. The protest had irritated Iranian diplomats in London, said Ratcliffe. “They were tweeting us, almost trolling us, on social media and various articles claiming I was breaking the Vienna convention. We have certainly got them crosser than we intended but part of the aim was to bring the problem to their doorstep so I’m glad that happened.” Johnson, who told a Commons committee when he was foreign secretary that Zaghari-Ratcliffe was “teaching people journalism” in Iran, should acknowledge his mistake, he said. Iranian officials cited his words as evidence that she had engaged in “propaganda against the regime”. The family have always maintained she was visiting relatives in Iran when she was arrested. She has strenuously denied spying. She was sentenced to five years in prison for attempting to overthrow the Iranian government. “Of course it’s not all [Johnson’s] fault,” said Ratcliffe. “Clearly we are camped here because the Iranian authorities are imprisoning Nazanin, but he should take responsibility for his mistakes because they have consequences. Not just the gaffe – the failure to apologise afterwards clearly made things worse. I think it’s bad for a candidate not to take responsibility for their mistakes because the most important thing for a prime minister is to take responsibility for their country.” He said he would press his wife’s case with whoever became leader. “We will be knocking on their door.” Foreign secretary and Johnson’s Tory leadership rival Jeremy Hunt this year granted Zaghari-Ratcliffe diplomatic protection in a bid to resolve her case. But Ratcliffe said the government needed to do more to protect British citizens unfairly imprisoned or tortured. “The Foreign Office always goes softly-softly and tries not to offend the other country, but sometimes you have to protect people more strongly. That shouldn’t be at the discretion of the foreign secretary. “People can be surprised the government has no legal obligation to protect you. That’s something parliament needs to change.” Kate Allen, director of Amnesty International UK, said Zaghari-Ratcliffe was “still a prisoner of conscience, still unfairly jailed after a sham trial, and still being subjected to the torment of separation from her home and family”.
